Atomically dispersed Rh on hydroxyapatite as an effective catalyst for tandem hydroaminomethylation of olefins Xiao Li a b Liusha Li a b Tingting Qin a b Gong Gun a b Tiejun Lin a Liangshu Zhong a c ⁎ a CAS Key Laboratory of Low-Carbon Conversion Science and Engineering, Shanghai Advanced Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai 201203, PR China CAS Key Laboratory of Low-Carbon Conversion Science and Engineering Shanghai Advanced Research Institute Chinese Academy of Sciences Shanghai 201203 PR China aCAS Key Laboratory of Low-Carbon Conversion Science and Engineering, Shanghai Advanced Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai 201203, PR China b University of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, PR China University of the Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 PR China bUniversity of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, PR China c School of Physical Science and Technology, ShanghaiTech University, Shanghai 201203, PR China School of Physical Science and Technology ShanghaiTech University Shanghai 201203 PR China cSchool of Physical Science and Technology, ShanghaiTech University, Shanghai 201203, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tandem hydroaminomethylation is an efficient and green route for one-pot synthesis of amines directly from olefins. Herein, heterogeneous hydroxyapatite (HAP) supported single-atom Rh catalyst was prepared and used for tandem hydroaminomethylation of olefins. Characterization techniques confirmed the atomic dispersion of Rh species on HAP. Up to 99% conversion of 1-hexene with high selectivity to the desired amines (93.2%) was obtained over 0.5Rh1/HAP catalyst. Mechanism study demonstrated that the first hydroformylation step during the tandem catalytic process was rate-determining. Compared with the Rh nanoparticles on other oxide supports (Mg3Al, MgO and Al2O3), the atomically dispersed Rh sites on HAP ensured the high hydroformylation activity, thereby guaranteed the outstanding catalytic performance for the total tandem process. Furthermore, various corresponding amines can be obtained with satisfactory yields over 0.5Rh1/HAP catalyst from a wide scope of olefins or amines substrates. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Atomically dispersed Rh Hydroxyapatite Tandem hydroaminomethylation Olefins 1 Introduction Amines are of great significance in the chemical and pharmaceutical industry with annual production in multimillion-ton scale [1]. Amines can be used as pharmaceutically and biologically active substances, dyes and fine chemicals [2]. Traditionally, the main methods for the amines synthesis include nucleophilic substitution reactions of alkyl halides, hydrocyanation of alkenes followed by reduction and reductive amination of carbonyl compounds (Scheme 1 ) [3–8]. However, the traditional processes always suffer from some serious drawbacks, such as usage of expensive or toxic feedstock and emission of environmentally harmful byproducts [9]. With ever-increasing environmental concern, amounts of efforts have been attributed to the development of efficient and green routes for the amines synthesis [10]. One of the elegant ways to produce amines directly from largely available olefins is tandem hydroaminomethylation, which is an atom-efficiently and environmentally friendly process (Scheme 1) [11]. In this tandem process, olefin is firstly converted to aldehydes via hydroformylation, which can react in situ with amine to form enamine by condensation reaction. Then the desired amine can be obtained via further hydrogenation [12,13]. Since hydroaminomethylation was firstly discovered by Reppe in 1949, tremendous efforts have been devoted to improve the catalytic efficiency and extend the substrate scope by optimization of ligands in the past decades [11,14–18]. In 1999, Eilbracht and coworkers found that rhodium salts or combination of rhodium salts with triphenylphosphine can be used as catalysts for hydroaminomethylation [19]. However, the regioselectivity was unsatisfactory and enormous difficulty existed to obtain pure products due to the similar properties of the linear and branched isomers. Later, Matthias Beller et al. developed a highly effective catalytic system consisting of a cationic rhodium precursor with Xantphos as ligand and the corresponding linear products were obtained with high regioselectivity when aliphatic olefins or styrene and its derivatives were used as substrates [16]. Linear amines can also be successfully prepared with high selectivity directly from the internal olefins or olefin mixtures through one-pot reaction consisting of initial olefin isomerization followed with hydroaminomethylation [15]. Despite homogeneous catalytic systems usually exhibited superior activity and selectivity in the hydroaminomethylation and related reactions, the separation of expensive noble metal and ligands from reaction mixture led to high energy consumption in the industry [20,21]. In this context, heterogeneous catalysts with the merit of easy product/catalyst separation were potential choices and worthy of more explorations [21–26]. However, to the best of our knowledge, the application of heterogeneous catalysts for hydroaminomethylation reaction was still scarce [9,27]. Ram S. Shukla et al. used rhodium complex encapsulated into the functionalized hexagonal mesoporous silica for hydroaminomethylation and obtained satisfactory catalytic performance. However, the functional groups on silica support by aminopropyl trimethoxysilane modification were easy to lose activity [9]. Hydroxyapatites (HAP) which possess abundant Ca2+ sites coordinated by PO4 3−, have been widely used as biomaterials, adsorbents and catalysts. Various transitional metals can be accommodated to the apatite framework as the catalytic active centers for olefin epoxidation, aerobic alcohol oxidation or hydrogenolysis etc. by the substitution of Ca2+ via cation exchange [28–32]. More importantly, the special surface structure of HAP is favorable for the preparation of highly dispersed or monomeric metal species [33–36]. For instance, Kazuya et al. revealed that the Ru species on HAP catalyst existed as monomeric Ru cations even with 17.1 wt% loading [31]. Zhang et al. proved that the Ni atomically dispersed species on HAP were highly active and completely coke-resistant for high temperature dry reforming of methane (750 °C) [37]. On the other hand, heterogeneous single-atom Rh-based catalysts have demonstrated outstanding catalytic performance in hydroformylation [21,23,26,38]. In this work, HAP was selected as support to prepare atomically dispersed Rh catalyst for tandem hydroaminomethylation of olefins. A complete olefin conversion with a high selectivity to the desired amines (93.2%) can be achieved over 0.5Rh1/HAP catalyst. The influences of reaction conditions on catalytic performance were studied in detail. A wide substrate scope of olefins or amines were explored for hydroaminomethylation over 0.5Rh1/HAP catalyst. In addition, the catalyst stability and catalytic mechanism were also investigated. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and reagents RhCl3•xH2O (35.0–42.0%), Ca(NO3)2•4H2O (99.0%), Mg(NO3)2•6H2O (99.0%), Al(NO3)3•9H2O (99.0%), ethanol (99.5%), diethylamine (99.5%), aniline (99.5%), and toluene (99.5%) were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. LTD. (NH4)2HPO4 (98.5%), 1-hexene (99.5%), 1-octene (97%), 1-decene (95%), styrene (95%) and heptanal (97%) were bought from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co. LTD. All chemicals were used as received without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation HAP support was firstly prepared through the coprecipitation method according to the previous reports [39]. Typically, a solution of calcium nitrate tetrahydrate (0.11 mol, 25.2 g) in 240 mL mixed solvent (ethanol/water = 1/1 in volume) and a solution of diammonium hydrogenphosphate (0.064 mol, 8.4 g) in 240 mL deionized water were prepared, respectively. The pH of both solutions was adjusted to 10.5 using aqueous ammonia (28 wt%) before mixing. Then the diammonium hydrogenphosphate solution was added dropwise into the calcium nitrate tetrahydrate solution and the pH of the solution was maintained at 10.5 during the process. After aging at 80 °C for 2 h, the obtained white precipitate via filtration was firstly dried at 120 °C overnight, and then calcined at 500 °C for 3 h. In addition, other metal oxide supports including MgO, Al2O3 and Mg3Al were prepared by coprecipitation method based on the previous report [40]. HAP supported catalysts with different Rh loading were prepared by ion exchange method. Typically, 1 g HAP was firstly dispersed into the 400 mL deionized water and then the required amount of RhCl3 aqueous solution was quickly added. After stirring at room temperature for 24 h, the powders were obtained by the filtration. The samples were firstly dried at 80 °C overnight, then calcined at 350 °C for 3 h. The samples with different theoretical Rh loading were denoted as xRh/HAP (x = 0.05, 0.1, 0.5 and 1 in wt%). For comparison, Rh supported on the other supports, including MgO, Al2O3 and Mg3Al, were prepared by traditional wet impregnation method. 2.3 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed on a Rigaku Ultima IV X-ray powder diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation with the wavelength of 1.54056 Å at 40 kV and 40 mA. The XRD patterns were obtained in a scanning angle (2θ) ranging from 20° to 90° with a scan peed of 4 °/min. The phase of samples was identified by comparing with JCPDS standard files. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption measurements were carried out on a Micromeritics TriStar 3020 instrument to study the textural properties of the catalysts. Approximate 50 mg samples were firstly degassed at 200 °C in vacuum for 6 h before measurements. Then the samples were transferred to the analysis station at −196 °C. The specific surface area was calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation. The total pore volume and average pore size were determined by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. The loading of Rh elements was measured on the inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, Optima 8000, Perkins Elmer) after the catalysts were dissolved according to the standard in-house procedures. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements for the catalysts were carried out on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer using the Al Kα (hν=1486 eV) radiation. The XPS spectra were analyzed through the Advantage software. Before fitting, all the spectra were calibrated based on the binding energy of the C 1 s neutral carbon peak at 284.8 eV. CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) experiments were conducted using a Micromeritics Autochem-II 2920 instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a MKS Cirrus 2 mass spectrometer. The sample was firstly pretreated under a helium flow of 30 mL/min at 200 °C for 2 h. After the temperature was cooled down to 50 °C, the gas was switched to pure CO2 at a flow rate of 30 mL/min for saturation adsorption. Then Ar gas (30 mL/min) was introduced to purge the residue CO2 in system. Once the TCD signals became stable, the temperature was increased from 50 to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C per minute in He with a flow rate of 30 mL/min. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) spectra were performed on a Thermo FTIR spectrometer (Nicolet IS50) with a MCT detector. Before the measurements, the samples were firstly pretreated at 200 °C for 30 min and then cooled to 50 °C in the He flow (20 mL/min). After the background spectrum (64 scans) was collected at 50 °C in Ar flow (20 mL/min) with resolution of 4 cm−1, the catalyst was exposed to CO for 1 h (10 mL/min) for saturation adsorption. Subsequently, in situ DRIFTS spectra were collected during the sweeping process with Ar (20 mL/min). For transmission electron microscopy (TEM) measurements, the samples were analyzed on a JEOL-JEM 2011 electron microscope with 200 kV accelerating voltage. High angle annular dark field-scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) was performed on JEOL ARM300F equipped with double aberration correctors and a cold field emission gun. The samples were prepared by dispersing the catalyst powder in ethanol followed by ultrasonication. One droplet of the suspension was dropped onto carbon-coated copper grids for measurements. 2.4 Catalytic test Catalytic evaluation: Hydroaminomethylation of olefins was carried out in a Teflon-line steel batch reactor (50 mL). Typically, 0.1 g catalyst, 5 mL of toluene, 5 mmol 1-hexene, 6 mmol diethylamine were added into the reactor in sequence. After the reactor was purged with CO for five times, the reactor was filled with 1 MPa CO and 3 MPa H2. The reactions were conducted at 60~140 °C with desired time. When the batch reactor was cooled down to room temperature, the residual gas was released and the liquid were withdrawn with injector for analysis. The filtrate were firstly analyzed by the gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS) equipped with an HP-5MS column (30 m length, 0.25 mm in diameter) to determine the structure of the products, then immediately analyzed by the gas chromatography (GC) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) to determine the product selectivity with dodecane as internal standard. Recycling experiments: The used catalyst was firstly collected by centrifugation and washed with water and ethanol to remove adsorbed reactants/products. Then the as-obtained sample was dried at 80 °C for 5 h and calcined under atmosphere at 350 °C for 3 h with a heating rate of 1 °C min−1 for next use. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization The as-prepared supported catalysts were firstly examined by XRD as shown in Fig. 1a. The patterns of supported Rh-based catalysts were identical with the corresponding supports (Fig. 1b). No obvious peaks belonged to Rh species were observed for all catalysts, indicating the highly dispersion of Rh on these supports. According to TEM characterization, the morphology of 0.5Rh1/HAP catalyst was similar with that of HAP support (Fig. S1), indicating that the supported Rh species didn't change the structure of HAP support. In addition, it was difficult to find obvious Rh nanoparticles or clusters (Fig. 1c) for 0.5Rh1/HAP catalyst. For a catalyst with 0.46 wt% loading, the absence of crystalline Rh or RhOx phase may reflect the formation of atomically dispersed Rh on HAP support. However, for 0.5Rh/Mg3Al, 0.5Rh/MgO and 0.5Rh/Al2O3 catalysts which contained almost similar Rh loading with 0.5Rh1/HAP catalyst, obvious Rh nanoparticles were observed, though the specific surface areas of MgO and Al2O3 supports were much higher than that of HAP (Table S1). In order to identify the nature of supported Rh on HAP, 0.5Rh1/HAP catalyst was further examined by aberration corrected HAADF-STEM. The obtained images clearly revealed the existence of isolated Rh atoms in 0.5Rh1/HAP catalyst (Fig. 2a). Moreover, the EDX-mapping results verified the homogeneous distribution of Rh species on HAP support (Fig. 2b and c). In situ DRIFTS of CO adsorption was an useful tool to explore the dispersion of Rh [23]. As displayed in Fig. 2d, two obvious peaks centered at 2096 cm−1 and 2024 cm−1, which were attributed to the symmetric and asymmetric vibration of gem-dicarbonyl double CO on the positively charged Rh atoms, gradually appeared with the increase of sweeping time. More importantly, the absence of bridging CO together with the lack of a coverage dependent shift of the linear Rh-CO strongly demonstrated that Rh atoms were highly dispersed and isolated from each other. The combination of HAADF-STEM and in situ DRIFTS of CO adsorption characterizations clearly confirmed the atomically dispersed Rh atoms, which were stabilized by the surface PO4 3- in the HAP support [28]. 3.2 Catalytic evaluation and the study of substrates scope Hydroaminomethylation of 1-hexene was firstly selected as the model reaction. The catalytic results were summarized in the Table 1 . No reaction took place without the addition of catalyst (Table 1, entry 1). The sole HAP support also showed no activity for this reaction (Table 1, entry 2). On the contrary, all of the as-prepared Rh-based catalysts can transform 1-hexene to the corresponding amines, suggesting the important role of supported Rh species for this tandem reaction. We firstly examined the catalytic performance of HAP supported Rh-based catalysts with different Rh loading (Table 1, entries 3–7). The amines selectivity gradually increased when the Rh loading increased from 0.05 wt% to 0.5 wt%. With further increasing the Rh loading to 1 wt%, the amines selectivity remained almost the same as that for 0.5Rh1/HAP catalyst. The increased Rh loading not only provided more active sites for the first hydroformylation step but also benefited for the last hydrogenation step. The selectivity toward byproducts, such as internal olefins and aldehydes, decreased with the increase of Rh loading. Moreover, the ratio of L/B gradually decreased as the more active Rh sites can enhance the condensation of diethylamine with branched aldehydes. These results demonstrated that 0.5Rh1/HAP catalyst can provide enough atomically dispersed Rh sites for this tandem catalytic process. A complete conversion of 1-hexene with amines selectivity of 93.2% and a low amount of byproducts was obtained over 0.5Rh1/HAP catalyst under mild reaction condition (Table 1 entry 5). However, the selectivities to the desired amines over other supported catalysts were much lower (Table 1 entries 8–10), indicating that the support may play an important role for this tandem catalytic process. As 0.5Rh1/HAP catalyst exhibited the most promising performance for this tandem reaction, it was selected as the model catalyst in the subsequent investigations. In order to study the substrates scope, the catalytic performance of 0.5Rh1/HAP catalyst using different olefins and amines as substrates were investigated and the results were listed in the Table 2 . It was found that a wide scope of aliphatic and aromatic terminal olefins, including 1-octene, 1-decene, cyclohexene and styrene can be converted into the corresponding amines. In general, 0.5Rh1/HAP catalyst exhibited extremely high activity for different olefins or amines. For 1-octene and 1-decene, the selectivities to the desired amines were 90.7% and 93.5%, respectively (Table 2, entries 1 and 2). Besides, a high selectivity to the targeted amines (93.8%) can also be obtained for cyclohexene (Table 2, entry 3). In the case of styrene, the selectivity to the corresponding amines was as high as 90.3% (Table 2, entry 4). It was worthy to note that a high ratio of linear to breached amines (2.2) with high conversion was obtained in this tandem process. Compared with the hydroformylation alone using the same heterogeneous catalysts, the higher selectivity to linear amines in this tandem reaction may be ascribed to the promoting effect in tandem process (Table S2). Furthermore, a high selectivity to the corresponding amines (77.3%) can still be achieved when diethylamine was replaced by aniline (Table 2, entry 5). 3.3 Effect of reaction conditions The effect of reaction conditions on catalytic performance for hydroaminomethylation of 1-hexene was studied in detail. The influence of reaction temperature was firstly explored. As shown in Fig. 3a, the yield of amines gradually increased from 77.8% to 93.2% as the reaction temperature increased from 60 °C to 120 °C. However, the yield of amines sharply declined to 82.7% when the reaction temperature was further increased to 140 °C. The yields of other byproducts including hexane, internal olefins and aldehydes were also affected by the variation of reaction temperature. At low reaction temperature (60 °C and 80 °C), the yield of internal olefins was about 10%. When the reaction temperature exceeded 80 °C, almost no internal olefins were left after reaction. This was due to the internal olefins was more difficult to be converted than the terminal olefins and the raise of reaction temperature was beneficial for the internal olefins conversion [41]. As for intermediate aldehydes, low reaction temperature (60 °C) or high reaction temperature (140 °C) would retard the condensation step and led to considerable amount of residual aldehydes after reaction (about 10%). Based on these results, it was easy to conclude that 120 °C was the suitable reaction temperature for this tandem process. Then the influence of reaction time was further studied. As displayed in Fig. 3b, the yield of amines increased sharply in the first six hours and then the growth rate gradually slowed down. In contrast, the yield of internal olefins showed a complete opposite trend. This phenomenon demonstrated that appropriate extension of reaction time was beneficial for the efficiency of this tandem process. The catalyst dosage can also affect the reaction. As expected, the yield of amines gradually increased from 70.0% to 93.2% when the catalyst dosage amount increased from 0.02 g to 0.1 g (Fig. 3c). However, no obvious increase of amines yield was observed when the catalyst dosage further increased to 0.2 g. The influence of hydrogen partial pressure was also investigated. As shown in Fig. 3d, the yield of amines gradually increased while the yield of internal olefins and aldehydes decreased with the increase of hydrogen partial pressure. Therefore, the enhancement of hydrogen partial pressure in the studied range was favorable for the improvement of the whole efficiency. 3.4 Reusability study Reusability of catalyst is of great significance from the viewpoint of practical application. After each reaction, the 0.5Rh1/HAP catalyst was firstly collected by centrifugation, and then washed with ethanol and deionized water and calcined at 350 °C before the next using. As shown in the Fig. S2, the yield of amines gradually declined while the yield of byproducts increased with the increasing the recycling time. In order to reveal the deactivation mechanism, the spent catalyst was carefully studied with different characterization techniques. The XRD pattern of spent catalyst was basically similar with that of fresh catalyst (Fig. S3). However, from the TEM images, the atomically dispersed Rh species were sintered into nanoparticles with the average particle size of 1.8 nm after reaction (Fig. S4). On the other hand, the ICP-OES results verified that the Rh content on HAP support decreased from 0.46 wt% to 0.15 wt%. The leaching Rh element was also found in the reaction mixture solution (0.0073 mg/ml). These results were consistent with the phenomenon that the yield of amines slowly increased from 41.5% to 73.3% even though the solid heterogeneous catalyst was removed from the catalytic system in hot filtration experiments (Fig. S5). Therefore, it was reasonable to conclude that the deactivation of catalyst was attributed to the growth of atomically dispersed Rh and Rh leaching via the formation of homogeneous Rh-carbonyls species. For further study, more efforts should be devoted to improve the stability of atomically dispersed Rh species on the HAP surface via catalyst design [36,42,43]. 3.5 Mechanism discussion In order to reveal the catalytic mechanism during the tandem hydroaminomethylation of 1-hexene, the catalytic performance of the as-prepared catalysts for each individual reaction steps were studied. In this tandem reaction, hydroformylation of 1-hexene to produce corresponding aldehydes was the first step (Scheme 2 ). According to the mechanism of heterogeneously catalyzed hydroformylation that derived from the mechanism for the homogeneously catalyzed hydroformylation proposed by Heck and Breslow, the Rh single atoms with carbonyl ligands were regarded as the active sites [44–46]. From the in situ DRIFTS of CO adsorption experiments, two obvious peaks located at 2096 cm−1 and 2024 cm−1 were associated with the symmetric and asymmetric stretches of the Rh(CO)2 gem-dicarbonyl species [21,23,47]. As shown in Fig. S6, the elementary steps for the first hydroformylation step comprise olefin coordination (1→2), olefin insertion (2→3), CO coordination (3→4), CO insertion (4→5), oxidative addition of H2 (5→6), and reductive elimination of the aldehyde (6→2). The catalytic performance for the sole hydroformylation was firstly carried out at the same reaction conditions as hydroaminomethylation except diethylamine was not added. As displayed in Fig. 4 a, distinct catalytic performances were obtained over the as-prepared catalysts. The selectivities to the corresponding aldehydes over 0.5Rh/Al2O3 and 0.5Rh1/HAP catalysts can be up to 96.7% and 98.5%, respectively. However, 0.5Rh/MgO catalyst exhibited much lower selectivity to aldehydes (73.3%) coupled with large amount of internal olefins (26.7%). Almost no aldehydes were formed over 0.5Rh/Mg3Al catalyst. Given to the basicity may have negative effects on the formation of aldehydes, CO2-TPD measurements were conducted [48,49]. Different from the other catalysts, 0.5Rh/Mg3Al catalyst exhibited two broader CO2 adsorption peaks, indicating the existence of abundant basic sites (Fig. S7). It was reasonable to speculate that the strong basicity of 0.5Rh/Mg3Al catalyst may be one of reasons for the poor catalytic performance in hydroformylation step. On the other hand, obvious Rh nanoparticles were observed for 0.5Rh/Al2O3, 0.5Rh/MgO and 0.5Rh/Mg3Al catalysts from the TEM images (Fig. 1d–f). In contrast, the Rh species on HAP support was atomically dispersed due to the excellent cation exchange ability of HAP originated from its special surface structure (Fig. 1f) [33]. Single-atom Rh-based catalysts always exhibited high catalytic performance for hydroformylation [21]. Therefore it was reasonable to conclude that the atomically dispersed Rh on HAP ensured the superior catalytic performance in hydroformylation. In addition, the catalytic performances of various catalysts in first hydroformylation can also affect the final products distribution in tandem hydroaminomethylation. For example, considerable internal olefins were left in both hydroformylation and tandem hydroaminomethylation reactions over 0.5Rh/MgO and 0.5Rh/Mg3Al catalysts (Table 1). Condensation of heptaldehyde with diethylamine and hydrogenation of enamine to produce amines were the following reaction step (Scheme 2). Condensation of aldehyde with diethylamine is a fast and sometimes uncatalysed step [50]. In order to exclude the influence of selected supports (Al2O3, MgO, Mg3Al and HAP) on condensation step, we compared the catalytic performance of the chosen supports for the condensation reaction at 120 °C under N2 atmosphere. As shown in the Fig. S8, there were no obvious differences for the yield of the intermediate enamine, demonstrating that the condensation of intermediate heptaldehyde with diethylamine can occur easily under this reaction condition and wasn't the determining step. Then the catalytic performance for the condensation of heptaldehyde with diethylamine in H2 atmosphere were evaluated as displayed in Fig. 3b. Different from the condensation under N2 atmosphere, the obtained enamine can be in situ converted to final amines with H2. [Rh]+ species were generally regarded the active sites for hydrogenation step (Fig. S6). The elementary steps include oxidative addition of H2 (10→7), enamine coordination (7→8), hydride transfer (8→9), reductive elimination of amines (9→10) [51]. The conversion of aldehyde was much higher for all the catalysts in H2 atmosphere, suggesting that the in situ conversion of enamine by hydrogenation was favorable for the improvement of conversion. Meanwhile, completely different product distributions were found over these catalysts under H2 atmosphere. No enamine was left for 0.5Rh/MgO catalyst. But the selectivity to enamine was 97.3% for 0.5Rh/Al2O3 catalyst, 17.0% for 0.5Rh/Mg3Al catalyst and 36.5% for 0.5Rh1/HAP catalyst, respectively. Combined with the results in Table 1, there were also enamine for 0.5Rh/Al2O3 (12.6%) and 0.5Rh/Mg3Al catalysts (20.7%) in this tandem reaction. This phenomenon revealed that the different hydrogenation ability of the as-prepared catalysts can affect the final product distributions. However, it was easy to find that no enamine was observed for 0.5Rh1/HAP catalyst in the tandem hydroaminomethylation of olefins though certain amount of enamine was left for 0.5Rh1/HAP catalyst (36.5%) in this control experiment. Based on these results, it is reasonable to speculate that the hydroformylation step was rate-determining for this tandem hydroaminomethylation reaction. The atomically dispersed Rh species of 0.5Rh1/HAP catalysts not only ensured the superior catalytic performance in hydroformylation, but also guaranteed the outstanding catalytic performance in the tandem hydroaminomethylation process. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have successfully developed Rh-based heterogenous catalytic system for one-pot synthesis of amines directly from the abundant and easily available olefins. Compared with the traditional routes, tandem hydroaminomethylation of olefins by heterogeneous catalysts was not only green and atom economical, but also avoided the complicate separation processes. Single-atom Rh catalyst supported on HAP was reported for the first time for amines productions from a wide substrates scope under mild condition. The experimental results demonstrated that the 0.5Rh1/HAP catalyst exhibited a complete olefin conversion with high selectivity to desired amines (93.2%) under optimized conditions. Meanwhile, mechanism study revealed that the first hydroformylation step was rate-determining. The atomically dispersed Rh species on HAP support ensured the high activity for hydroformylation, thereby guaranteed the outstanding catalytic performance during the tandem hydroaminomethylation process. coredata.dc:description: Tandem hydroaminomethylation is an efficient and green route for one-pot synthesis of amines directly from olefins. Herein, heterogeneous hydroxyapatite (HAP) supported single-atom Rh catalyst was prepared and used for tandem hydroaminomethylation of olefins. Characterization techniques confirmed the atomic dispersion of Rh species on HAP. Up to 99% conversion of 1-hexene with high selectivity to the desired amines (93.2%) was obtained over 0.5Rh1/HAP catalyst. Mechanism study demonstrated that the first hydroformylation step during the tandem catalytic process was rate-determining. Compared with the Rh nanoparticles on other oxide supports (Mg3Al, MgO and Al2O3), the atomically dispersed Rh sites on HAP ensured the high hydroformylation activity, thereby guaranteed the outstanding catalytic performance for the total tandem process. Furthermore, various corresponding amines can be obtained with satisfactory yields over 0.5Rh1/HAP catalyst from a wide scope of olefins or amines substrates.
coredata.dc:title: Atomically dispersed Rh on hydroxyapatite as an effective catalyst for tandem hydroaminomethylation of olefins
